newsitem.title: USA: Wall Steet shares hurt by profit-taking at midday.
newsitem.headline: Wall Steet shares hurt by profit-taking at midday.

text.p: U.S. stocks were battered by profit-taking at midday Thursday, giving up some of the stunning gains triggered by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony to Congress on the economy.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average, which soared earlier in the week when Greenspan allayed concerns about a possible rise in interest rates, was off around 89 points to 7999.
The Nasdaq composite slid about 10 points to 1558.
The long bond, strong at the start of the session, slipped 2/32 to yield 6.44 percent.

"It's nothing but profit-taking," said John Cleland, chief investment strategist at Security Benefit Group of Cos. "We get these huge run-ups in a day or two, then people start to take some profits out of the market."
The profit-taking was widespread and came despite solid corporate earnings announcements and a rosy outlook for the U.S. economy, analysts said.

"There are still some investors who are concerned about valuations," said Robert Froelich, chief investment strategist at Kemper Funds. "These declines are certainly not driven by earnings disappointments or inflation concerns."
Analysts said most second quarter earnings have come in as forecast or higher than Wall Street estimates, providing support for the equities markets.

Digital Equipment Corp reported fiscal fourth quarter profits of $0.75 per share, compared to a loss of $2.87 a year earlier, which included $492 million in restructuring charges. The First Call consensus estimate was $0.73 per share. The company said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 15 million shares.
Colgate-Palmolive Co posted second quarter earnings of $0.58 per share versus $0.49 in the year-ago quarter and a First Call estimate of $0.56. The stock gained 1/16 to 75-7/16.
AirTouch Communications Inc surged after reporting second quarter earnings of $0.21 per share, against Wall Street's estimate of $0.14.
"Earnings reports have been very good," said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments.
But breadth was negative, with declining issues leading gainers on the New York Stock Exchange by eight to five.
"Transports are weak...bonds are weak, Nasdaq's weak -- it's profit-taking more than anything else," said Warren Epstein, director of trading at Richard Rosenblatt.
The Dow Transport index shed 32 points to 2876.
Delta Air Lines lost 11/16 to 87-1/2 after posting fourth quarter earnings of $3.98 per primary share, compared to $2.69 a year ago. The First Call estimate was $4.03.
Mallinckrodt Inc agreed to buy medical products supplier Nellcor Puritan Bennett Inc in a deal valued at $1.9 billion. Nellcor rose 7-1/8 to 28-1/16.
